Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real-valued functions representing position in 2D space over time t. Transformations are applied via \\( g(z) = e^{At}z \\), where \\( A \\) is a complex constant.

Knowing the position \\( z(T) \\) at time T, is it possible to uniquely determine \\( z_0 \\) without confirmation whether \\( g(z) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without knowing if the transformation \\( g(z) \\) was applied, reconstructing the initial position \\( z_0 \\) is ambiguous. The function \\( e^{At} \\) could have altered the trajectory significantly, thus without this knowledge, accurate inference of \\( z_0 \\) directly from \\( z(T) \\) is mathematically infeasible.

causal_map_integration: The position at time T (z(T)) depends on the initial position z_0. The transformation g(z) parameterized by A transforms z into g(z). Knowing z(T) allows us to infer z_0 if g(z) was applied.
